body:
In general, merging this into 1.0 is fine once the following remaining issues are addressed:

1) Remove the integration from LibMatrixMult and call it either from MatrixBlock or even better from individual instructions. I'd like to keep LibMatrixMult a pure java library - remember that we want to isolate the entire matrix block library as an individual jar in the near future. 

2) Improve the conditions for selecting native BLAS libraries. I find the condition of dispatching all dense matrix-matrix multiplications too optimistic.

3) Please also cleanup the minor code issues as highlighted below.

@mboehm7 I will incorporate your suggestions today.

[All tests](https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/1326/) passed.

I believe this is correct. Thank you @asurve.

LGTM.
cc @dusenberrymw
LGTM. Thank you @dusenberrymw!
cc @niketanpansare Just FYI that the `nn` library should work once we start packaging it in the JAR soon due to this addition.

Awesome !! Thanks @deroneriksson for adding this feature :+1: 

@dusenberrymw Looking forward to moving nn from staging to scripts :)

Absolutely. I want to merge this earlier (as soon as we get go-ahead from current RC) to give us about 2-3 months to **test performance/robustness** on different hardware, OS, BLAS, configurations, networks, workloads, etc. :)

@asurve This is a good reason to have a 0.14 branch. Cutting all the 0.14 RCs from master is causing delays, which means our next release will need to be postponed or won't be tested as thoroughly as it otherwise could be.

I am not clear why this change is waiting for 1.0 based (or major) release.
If you are adding new functionality as a experimental feature until its fully ready, you can add it on regular interval, as far as it does not breaks supported functionality. You don't need to wait for major release.
Are we breaking any backward compatibility? if yes, then it justifies for separate branch for major release.
Are we changing BLAS from Java-based BLAS to native BLAS? Does it causes break in the backward compatibility for users?
Are there any other changes which may cause potential issues in currently supported functionality?

@niketanpansare Please provide details on your concerns for not adding to current master branch.

@asurve Right now we can't commit major updates to master because the RCs are being cut directly from master rather than from a dedicated 0.14 branch. Introducing a major commit such as this PR going from one 0.14 RC to the next 0.14 RC would not be advisable since all the RCs are being cut from the master branch. I don't understand this change of not having a 0.14 branch. For 0.13, we had a 0.13 branch and cherry-picked RC updates on to the 0.13 branch (see https://github.com/apache/incubator-systemml/commit/83f56f30d521152a68e83e698819121624fd97b7).

>> Are we breaking any backward compatibility? 

No.

>> Are we changing BLAS from Java-based BLAS to native BLAS? 

Yes.

>> Please provide details on your concerns for not adding to current master branch.

This feature depends on BLAS, which in turn depends on the OS and other configuration. Hence, before we add it to a release, we have to test this feature on different setup.

@asurve The master branch is always reserved for the bleeding edge of the project.  Any releases should be placed on separate release branches.  We can't merge in large features that could introduce bugs elsewhere in the system randomly in the middle of two release candidates if we're using the master branch for our release candidates.

EDIT: Just to clarify, this PR should be merged onto `master`, whereas the release candidates for 0.14 should be continued on a separate `0.14` branch.

@niketanpansare thanks for clarification.

We need to have another RC sooner, will have RC and branch as well. That should work for you, right?

Instrumentation displaying the accuracy showed the score above 95% most of the time.  Occasionally the result was at or below the test threshold of 0.95 resulting in a test failure.  For example, one failure was exactly 0.95, another slightly below at 0.94444.

First tried intercept 2 by using normalize=True and keeping fit_intercept default value of false.  However, this was invalid based on resulting program exception:
`
Caused by: org.apache.sysml.runtime.DMLScriptException: Stopping due to invalid argument: Currently supported intercept options are 0 and 1
        at org.apache.sysml.runtime.instructions.cp.ScalarBuiltinCPInstruction.processInstruction(ScalarBuiltinCPInstruction.java:64)
`

Next tried disabling regularization with C=float("inf") but observed a failure where accuracy as low as 0.92777.

Then changed tolerance to 0.001 based on default value from scripts/algorithms/m-svm.dml and test/scripts/applications/m-svm/m-svm.pydml.  Accuracy was observed between 0.977 and 0.994.  Note the default parameters in python/systemml/mllearn/estimators.py were kept as-is.

LGTM - thanks @gweidner. As a nice to have could you try tol=0.0001 as that's the default of sklearn.LinearSVC. Unfortunately, the documentation does not tell if this is a target or per iteration tolerance but if it is - similar to our algorithm - a target tolerance then I'd like to use consistent parameters for comparison.
Thank you for reviewing Matthias - much appreciated!  Good point regarding tolerance - let me retry with tol=0.0001.  Before this PR I had only used the default value in estimators.py of 0.000001.

I ran a series of experiments at `tol=0.0001` where I ran test_svm only and always printed the accuracy.  The results looked good as twice an accuracy of 1.0 was reported.  Also repeated the full test_mllearn_numpy group with test_svm at `tol=0.0001` using updated commit.  Since all 7 tests passed as well, merging to master.

I would recommend not using the name `systemml.py` as our python api has a module with the same name. 

So as to know the reasoning behind this PR, is it fair to assume that having one single python file for all environment help simplify developer testing ?
something like run_systemml or launch_systemml ?

@niketanpansare  - Changed the name to `systemml-standalone.py`.
There will be a corresponding `systemml-spark-submit.py`, `systemml-spark-shell.py` and `systemml-pyspark-shell.py` (if those make sense).

>> systemml-standalone.py. There will be a corresponding systemml-spark-submit.py, systemml-spark-shell.py and systemml-pyspark-shell.py

If possible, I would recommend creating a single script and handling different scenarios within it using parameters. Likely I am missing some context; can you explain why we would need systemml-spark-submit.py, systemml-spark-shell.py and systemml-pyspark-shell.py ? Would it not simply invoke spark-submit with --jars or --driver-class-path ?

>>  I think it will be useful to have a single script for all environments, but we should make a decision and deprecate the other scripts if we prefer this one.

+1.

We can discuss whether one script with Args is better or more. Personally I prefer having more to clearly separate the different entry points into SystemML. This is much like Spark. A separate script for pyspark, spark-submit, etc.

Multiple files/entry points has higher chance of inconsistencies as evident from our APIs. Since this PR doesnot add other files and since this is intended for developers, I am OK with this PR :+1:  ... When we plan to make it available to general audience, I would recommend discussing it on our mailing list.

As a side note, I understand other committers might have different views on this, but I am not fan of having wrapper invocation scripts over standard programs (such as java, spark-submit, pyspark, spark-shell). I would prefer better documentation of usage rather than hiding them in these scripts. For example: we simply ask users to invoke SystemML using
`java -cp target/*:SystemML.jar -f ...` or `spark-submit SystemML.jar -f ...` or `pyspark --driver-class-path SystemML.jar --jars SystemML.jar -f ..`.

Thank you for the `ok` on this PR  

Well, `spark` does have different scripts. And they hide the messy invocation behind scripts. I would suggest that we should learn from it what we can.
I suspect what will probably end up happening is that people will create scripts on their own if we don't. 

I am a fan of documentation.

well, I kind of agree with both sides here: currently, I use my custom sparkDML2.sh scripts to simplify the invocation through spark_submit. I don't use sparkDML.sh for the reason Niketan brought up: we want to feed our flags unchanged into such as script, while sparkDML requires to modify dash to dash dash (for consistency with shell script conventions) and some flags cannot be passed at all.
how about extending sparkDML.sh ?
@bertholdreinwald - that is the next step. Either I or the GSoC student can work on it (assuming the project goes through). I was thinking of redoing the sparkDML as a python script.

LGTM, I particularly like multiple GPU context. I would recommend waiting for 0.14 branch to be created. Also, it would be nice if we double-check setGPU feature with this PR. I can test setGPU feature on deep-learning networks once https://github.com/apache/incubator-systemml/pull/422 is merged in :)
Thank you for reviewing @dusenberrymw!
All [tests](https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/1335/) passed.
All [tests](https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/1338/) passed on jenkins. Unless anyone has feedback or suggestions, I would like to merge this PR.
@nakul02 Can you please rebase this PR with master ? I want to run some sanity tests on it.
Will do, thanks!
@niketanpansare  - rebased against master.

Thanks @nakul02 ... I noticed that when setGPU is enabled, we initialize CUDA, but no GPU instructions gets invoked.

Here is a simple scala script to test it:

```scala
import org.apache.sysml.api.mlcontext._
import org.apache.sysml.api.mlcontext.ScriptFactory._
val ml = new MLContext(spark)
ml.setGPU(true)
ml.setStatistics(true)
val script = dml("X = rand(rows=100, cols=100); print(sum(X %*% t(X)));")
ml.execute(script)
```


I have also tested it with my wrappers and observe the same behavior.
Can you please try setting the `force=true` argument ?
we donot have `force=true` in mlcontext :(
for now, can you either quickly add one, or just hard-code in the source and try it out?

How about
```
scala> org.apache.sysml.api.DMLScript.FORCE_ACCELERATOR = true
```

I tried running above script **without** `force` on current master and it works.

great, thanks @niketanpansare & @deroneriksson 
does it work on this PR?

To summarize,
1. Current master: works without force
2. This PR: works with force, but not without force.

If this is known issue that you intend to fix in subsequent PR, then LGTM for this PR.

I am still struggling with my local environment to see it working.
Also, prior to deciding between preference (1) and (2), I'd like to understand all the dependencies first required for a successful deployment.

I like approach 2. Its much like JCuda, which we are already using.
(I didn't like the name systemml-accelerator, it would imply that backends other than a pure Java implementation would live in that project).

Definitely either (1) or (2).  Option (3) will definitely complicate deployment.  I think I like option 2, perhaps paired with some optional platform-specific builds that do include the extra jar within our uber jar.  That way, we could still build & release just the plain jar that relies on the user including the appropriate blas jar on the classpath, but also have the option to build and release platform-specific jars by including the appropriate native blas jar (and appropriate jcuda jar) into our uber jar.  The platform-specific jars would just be for user convenience.

@niketanpansare, @dusenberrymw, does this look good to you?
Can I merge?

@niketanpansare 
I shall, since 0.14 is now on a separate branch, can I merge this?

Since 0.14 is on a separate branch I am planning on merging this.
@dusenberrymw, @deroneriksson, @niketanpansare - is that ok to do?
LGTM :+1:
LGTM :+1:  ... please fix the force issue in a separate PR.
Can you please resolve the conflicts ? I would like to test it before giving LGTM.

Please note that option 2 can be further divided into:
- Option 2a: Platform-independent jar but in SystemML project - something along the lines of systemml-1.0.0-blas.jar. Pros: Simpler to support in pip. Cons: Few more KBs added to the jar.
- Option 2b: Platform-dependent jar but in SystemML project - Cons: Simpler to support in pip. For example: we **donot support GPU via pip**.
- Option 2c: As a separate project - Cons: Release process more difficult.

I recommend that we either go with option 1 or option 2a. If we come up with a solution for supporting GPU via pip, we can then go with option 2b instead of option 2a.
@niketanpansare - on it

I'm in favor of (2) - in addition to the size of the jar, it also affects build time, and it removes the tensorflow package from our jar which might confuse people to think SystemML has a tensorflow dependency.

Passed [tests ](https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/1353/)
@niketanpansare  - could you please test this out, I will merge when I have your ok, thanks.

For certain deployment scenarios, people ask for a "as small as possible" footprint SystemML jar file as they only want to use some limited, core capability of SystemML, e.g. do not want to use caffe proto, or MR/Spark backend, just fast in-memory Java processing. These scenarios give the 1st option a strong -1.

Thanks Berthold and Matthias for your feedback. I guess we are all in agreement that bundling Caffe2DML separately is the way to go.

Nakul, Mike, Arvind, Deron: Can you please provide your feedback as this PR introduces another artifact in our release ?

Today we have single jar file for deployment. By having multiple artifacts/jar files, how deployment will be handled? 
In the cluster environment do we expect user to configure every node with additional artifact/jar file?

First off, WRT build time, I really don't think build time is an issue. Adding a few seconds to a project build seems trivial if this adds useful functionality that will help users. If anything, splitting to a separate jar built in the same project might increase build time compared to packaging this in the same jar. However, I only think build time is an issue if it did something like add a minute or more to the build, and even then I would think that is fine if it adds critical functionality to the project.

Having a separate jar created by the project's pom adds additional complexity to our build. This makes the pom even more difficult to maintain. So with regards to build maintenance, (1) is better than (2). That said, I'm a little bit frustrated by the 75 java warnings that get introduced to the project from protobuf-generated classes, but I'm not sure what can be done there. Personally I like to have 0 java warnings in a project. That way, I can easily see in my IDE if I have introduced new java warnings, whereas if there is a big pool of java warnings already, it gets harder to spot the ones that I might be introducing.

Also, if there is an additional artifact (2), please be aware that it should have the required LICENSE, NOTICE, and DISCLAIMER files and the LICENSE needs to accurately reflect the contents of the jar. Also, tasks such as artifact validation and integrating the additional artifact into the release process need to be considered.

I have renamed `systeml-*-caffe2dml.jar` to `systeml-*-extra.jar` . We can use it to include BLAS dependency as well.

>> Today we have single jar file for deployment. By having multiple artifacts/jar files, how deployment will be handled? In the cluster environment do we expect user to configure every node with additional artifact/jar file?

The user has to add the additional jar into `--jars` command, no need to configure every node.

>> First off, WRT build time, I really don't think build time is an issue.  Adding a few seconds to a project build seems trivial if this adds useful functionality that will help users.

I agree.

>> That said, I'm a little bit frustrated by the 75 java warnings that get introduced to the project from protobuf-generated classes, but I'm not sure what can be done there.

I too don't like to warning. This is a known issue in protobuf with Java 8: https://github.com/google/protobuf/issues/304

>> Also, if there is an additional artifact (2), please be aware that it should have the required LICENSE, NOTICE, and DISCLAIMER files and the LICENSE needs to accurately reflect the contents of the jar.

Thanks @deroneriksson  I have added META-INF of the current jar into the `extra` jar. Can someone help me with the LICENSE for the `extra` jar ?

I prefer option (1).  At this point, adding an additional jar artifact just complicates the project further, and will lead to confusion on how to actually use SystemML for Caffe-based deep learning using the Caffe2DML API.  Additionally, when we add Keras support as well, this will likely share much of the infrastructure from Caffe2DML, and I don't want to have to create yet another "Keras2DML" jar.

As for the lightweight deployment, that certainly is a viable use-case.  However, I would prefer to have an optional "lightweight" profile for that scenario that simply builds a true minimal version of the project, rather than have the main jar be somewhat small.  This would not be released as a download for our releases, but would be available as an optional maven build, just like our current Java-only standalone build profile.

I agree with @dusenberrymw about (1). I like his idea of having a lightweight jar rather than limiting the main jar. Also if truly lightweight is a goal, then I think the hadoop dependency requirements should be removed from JMLC execution. I haven't tried it lately, but I believe JMLC execution requires at minimum hadoop-auth (67K), hadoop-common (3.4M), hadoop-mapreduce-client-core (1.5M), and possibly guava (1.6M) as a transitive dependency of these.

Just to clarify the build time issue: people like me build SystemML 10s to 100s of times a day; from my perspective our build time is borderline right now - I find myself increasingly often switching tasks while the build is running which distracts the dev workflow. So not including this tool into the core build process would help keeping the build time low.

And I absolutely agree with regard to the introduced warnings. Hopefully, excluding caffe2dml from our build, will also resolve this issue.
@niketanpansare isn't there also a fourth option that removes the tensorflow classes and only adds the core dml generation? This would kind of combine all advantages.

>>  isn't there also a fourth option that removes the tensorflow classes and only adds the core dml generation? This would kind of combine all advantages.

The warnings are coming from files generated by caffe.proto, not tensorflow's proto files. The fourth option (if I understand correctly) would involve:
- Create a separate repository that will be managed by some committer X (not Apache !!!).
- This repo will compile the java classes from caffe.proto and tensorflow.proto
- X will go through necessary open-source related process and then host it on either central maven or private maven repo on github.
- SystemML will then have an explicit provided/compile dependency on a privately managed project.

no, I was just wondering why we need these tensorflow classes at all - at the end of the day it's just about parsing some input specification and generating dml. I'm still in favor of having caffe2dml in the SystemML repository but it would be great to smooth out the build issues.

Regarding the Java warnings in Eclipse for the generated source files, I just tried the solution posted here and it removed the warnings for the generated source files: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1127920/how-to-suppress-java-warnings-for-specific-directories-or-files-such-as-generate

Given that I can suppress these warnings, I am happier with the (1) solution. :-)
I shall merge, thank you
Thanks, I shall merge
Ran few sanity tests to validate this PR. LGTM Thanks @nakul02 :+1:

>>  I'm still in favor of having caffe2dml in the SystemML repository but it would be great to smooth out the build issues.
>> Given that I can suppress these warnings

Great !! Once we agree to a solution, Deron can resolve the warning in a separate PR.

>> I am happier with the (1) solution.
>>  However, I would prefer to have an optional "lightweight" profile for that scenario that simply builds a true minimal version of the project, rather than have the main jar be somewhat small.

If we all agree to solution (1), I am happy to create a "lightweight" profile.

>> why we need these tensorflow classes

TensorFlow classes are required for [tensorboard integration with Caffe2DML](https://github.com/apache/incubator-systemml/blob/master/src/main/python/systemml/mllearn/estimators.py#L615). In future, this will allow us to plot histograms, network, etc.

![capture](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11686380/25297007/128c9814-26a0-11e7-95d5-8c47c03f4d06.PNG)
Great, I shall merge. Thanks for the review and feedback @deroneriksson, @dusenberrymw, @niketanpansare and @mboehm7.

thanks @dusenberrymw I gave it a try on our ARIMA application testcase which historically was challenging for scalar propagation. Unfortunately, it failed due to an - probably unrelated - issue in replaceLiteralFullUnaryAggregate. Once I resolved this, I'll play around with it a bit more. 

Once this PR is in, we should also think about the problem of propagating scalars into functions if functions are called once or with consistent scalar inputs.

@mboehm7 Great, interested to see what else is needed for this to be generally applicable.  Also, definitely +1 for propagating scalars into functions.  In particular, we should allow for the case of functions for which any subset of the inputs are consistent scalars.  I.e., a function may have an unknown matrix size as an input, but then have several other scalar inputs that are always consistent.

Thanks, @mboehm7.  Looks like it is failing a test still -- `org.apache.sysml.test.integration.functions.misc.DataTypeChangeTest#testDataTypeChangeValidate4c`.  Looking into it, it fails due to trying to cast a Matrix to a Scalar object.  At a deeper level, it looks like the propagated variable map is holding onto the "matrix" `X`, rather than dropping it as it should, since X is turned into a scalar by the call `X = foo(X)`.  Interestingly, the FunctionOp for the `foo` function is marked as having an `Unknown` datatype and valuetype.  That to me seems to be  big issue, but I'm not sure exactly where that is failing.  Thoughts?  Overall, this seems like a bug that was just hidden before, rather than being newly introduced.

yes this is almost certainly a bug - originally we allowed data type changes in conditional control flow (e.g., if branch assigns a scalar and else branch a matrix), in which case we assign UNKNOWN for subsequent references. However, I modified this years ago because SystemML could not compile valid instructions for these scenarios unless we extend the recompiler to actually update the data type and block sizes there.
Build failed, see build log for details

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder//job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/1370/
By the way, aside from that test, everything else passed.

@akchinSTC I see the link is going to https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder//job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/1370/ instead of https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/1370/

There is a PR against this branch - https://github.com/niketanpansare/incubator-systemml/pull/12
In a previous PR, I had added some documentation. For some reason, [this](https://github.com/niketanpansare/incubator-systemml/pull/11/files#diff-9e37a6d0b34a78b71e23a45024101f67) documentation was removed and a [truncated](https://github.com/niketanpansare/incubator-systemml/blob/switch_blas/docs/blas.md) version was introduced along with a [shell script](https://github.com/niketanpansare/incubator-systemml/blob/switch_blas/src/main/cpp/compile-lib-linux-x86_64.sh).

In my opinion, having a script to do builds in this situation is an incorrect approach.
